title: How Gov. Andrew Cuomo Could Be Impeached: What to Know
sub_head: Several women have accused Cuomo of sexual harassment; Democratic governor denies the allegations
body:
Investigators for state Attorney General Letitia James concluded in an early August report that Mr. Cuomo broke state and federal sexual-harassment laws by inappropriately touching or making comments to 11 women, including current and former aides and state workers. The report was commissioned last spring, following a series of allegations by several of the women, which also helped prompt an impeachment investigation by the New York state Assembly.
As part of its impeachment probe, the assembly is also examining Mr. Cuomo’s handling of Covid-19 deaths at nursing-home facilities and whether he used state resources in the production of his pandemic memoir.
The Democratic governor has denied inappropriately touching anybody and said Ms. James’s review was biased. One of his accusers, an executive assistant to the governor, has filed a criminal complaint with the Albany County Sheriff’s Office, saying Mr. Cuomo groped her in his office. Mr. Cuomo’s lawyers have said he never groped the woman.
State officials said their nursing-home policies were crafted to preserve hospital capacity at the height of the pandemic and were in line with federal guidance at the time. Rich Azzopardi, a spokesman for Mr. Cuomo, has said some state officials volunteered to work on the book and any other use of state resources was incidental.
The Assembly initiates an impeachment and assumes the role of prosecutor and grand jury. After an inquiry and hearings, the 150-member Assembly, where Democrats outnumber Republicans by more than two to one, will vote on the articles of impeachment.
